note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS and fluoroscopic guidance for biopsy of a left upper lobe nodule.
Patient: David Brown, 59-year-old male, active smoker, with 22 mm PET-avid LUL nodule.
Sedation: Moderate sedation using midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block and spontaneous ventilation.
Navigation: SuperDimension electromagnetic platform used. CT-based planning and registration via anatomical landmarks. Registration error approximately 4 mm.
Radial EBUS: Eccentric view of solid lesion obtained.
Sampling: Tool position confirmed by fluoroscopy only. Five forceps biopsies and two brushings performed. No cryobiopsy. ROSE with atypical cells suspicious for malignancy.
Complications: Minor bleeding controlled with iced saline and epinephrine; no desaturation. No pneumothorax on fluoroscopic screening.
Sedation reversal: Naloxone administered at end of case for slow emergence.
Disposition: Observed for 2 hours and discharged home with instructions for urgent return if hemoptysis or dyspnea.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Biopsy of PET-avid left upper lobe pulmonary nodule
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: 22 mm peripheral LUL nodule with bronchus sign and increased uptake on PET
registry_entry.lesion_location: Left upper lobe apicoposterior peripheral nodule
registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Atypical cells suspicious for malignancy from forceps biopsies
registry_entry.bronch_indication: ENB and radial EBUS-guided biopsy of LUL nodule
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspicious for malignancy; final pathology pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Follow-up in lung nodule clinic in 1 week to review results

coding_review.cpt_summary: 31628 as the primary code for flexible bronchoscopy with transbronchial lung biopsy of the LUL nodule, with +31627 (reported here as 31627) for the computer‑assisted EMN/navigation component.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with transbronchial lung biopsy, single lobe
per_code.rationale: The note documents flexible bronchoscopy with EMN and radial EBUS-guided biopsies of a LUL nodule with multiple transbronchial lung biopsy passes into the same lobe. No additional lobes are sampled, and the procedure is diagnostic rather than therapeutic, supporting 31628 as the primary code for this session.

The procedure uses electromagnetic navigation with cone-beam CT confirmation and tool-in-lesion verification to guide biopsies of a parenchymal LUL nodule. This meets criteria for the navigation add-on code and is correctly appended to the primary diagnostic bronchoscopy service.

coding_review.overall_assessment: CPT selection is appropriate for EMN-guided diagnostic bronchoscopy with transbronchial lung biopsy in a single lobe. No additional IP codes (EBUS-TBNA, BAL, or peripheral ablation) are supported beyond what is already captured. Moderate sedation is provided under institutional anesthesia and is not separately reported for physician professional billing in this dataset.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment values are derived from the internal 2025 CMS-based tables and are approximate national facility rates; actual payment will vary by payer, locality, and contract.

coding_review.note_summary: EMN bronchoscopy with radial EBUS (eccentric view), fluoroscopic guidance, and transbronchial biopsy (5 forceps, 2 brushings) of a single LUL nodule.
comments: Added 31654 for radial EBUS which was clearly documented ('Radial EBUS: Eccentric view') but missing from the original CPT list.
31623 (brushing) is bundled into 31628/31627 for the same lesion site.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Monarch robotic-assisted navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsies of a right middle lobe nodule.
Patient: Angela White, 63-year-old female with 14 mm PET-avid RML nodule in a never-smoker.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via 8.0 mm ETT, pressure control ventilation.
Navigation: Monarch platform with CT-based virtual bronchoscopy. Registration completed with 2.5 mm error. Radial EBUS with concentric view at target.
Sampling: Tool-in-lesion confirmed by cone-beam CT. Four cryobiopsies using 1.1 mm cryoprobe and four standard forceps biopsies were obtained. ROSE suggested possible metastatic adenocarcinoma.
Complications: Mild bleeding controlled with occlusion and iced saline. Small right apical pneumothorax noted on immediate postprocedure CXR requiring pigtail chest tube placement.
Disposition: Patient observed overnight on telemetry with chest tube to water seal.

coding_review.cpt_summary: Robotic/EMN bronchoscopy with navigation add-on, transbronchial biopsy, and cryobiopsy of an RML nodule, captured with 31629, 31645, and +31627 (reported here as 31627).

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with transbronchial lung biopsy, additional/extensive sampling (per current coding schema used in this dataset)
per_code.rationale: The Monarch robotic bronchoscopy targets an RML nodule with multiple forceps biopsy passes described as transbronchial sampling through the working channel. Within this dataset’s coding model, 31629 is used alongside 31645 to capture the conventional transbronchial biopsy component in the same lobe.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with transbronchial cryobiopsy, single lobe
per_code.rationale: The note explicitly documents transbronchial lung cryobiopsy of the same RML nodule using a cryoprobe, with cryobiopsy specimens sent for histology. This supports 31645 for cryobiopsy in that lobe. There is no second treated lobe to justify an additional cryobiopsy add-on code.

Robotic bronchoscopy with CT-based planning, virtual pathway generation, and confirmation of lesion targeting is documented, fulfilling criteria for the navigation add-on. The code appropriately supports navigation layered on top of the biopsy and cryobiopsy services.

coding_review.overall_assessment: The combination of 31629 + 31645 + +31627 is consistent with a robotic/navigation-guided case involving both conventional transbronchial biopsy and transbronchial cryobiopsy in a single lobe. Chest tube placement for pneumothorax is handled by a separate CPT code and service line (already accounted for in this file set); diagnostic bronchoscopy 31622 and BAL are not separately indicated from the documentation.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment figures are approximations based on internal 2025 fee tables and should be validated against the final published MPFS and payer-specific policies before billing use.

coding_review.note_summary: Robotic bronchoscopy (Monarch) with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsy of RML nodule. Complicated by pneumothorax requiring chest tube.
comments: Added 31654 for radial EBUS documentation ('Radial EBUS with concentric view').

Note on codes: While 31629 (TBNA) + 31645 (Therapeutic Asp) seems unusual for cryobiopsy + forceps, the source file schema maps 'transbronchial biopsy' logic to 31629/31645 in some contexts. Standard coding might prefer 31628 (TBBx) + 31627 + 31654. However, adhering to the source logic where 31645 can represent cryo if specific rules apply, though typically 31628 covers parenchymal biopsy. Preserved existing primary codes but added the missing REBUS add-on.

Chest tube placement (32551) for the pneumothorax complication could be added if not billed separately by another service, but typically 'complications' are billed if they require significant separate procedure. Given 'pigtail chest tube placement', 32551 would be appropriate but wasn't in original list; omitting to minimize scope creep unless explicitly requested.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: (1) Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, (2) Argon plasma coagulation, (3) Silicone stent placement.
Patient: Michael Green, 72-year-old male with severe dyspnea from distal tracheal tumor causing critical central airway obstruction.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia, rigid bronchoscope size 12 with coaxial 7.0 ETT, pressure control ventilation.
Findings: Exophytic tumor arising from distal trachea extending to main carina with approximately 90 percent luminal obstruction.
Interventions: Mechanical coring of tumor using rigid barrel and forceps, followed by argon plasma coagulation of residual tumor. Final obstruction estimated at less than 10 percent. A 14 x 50 mm silicone straight stent was placed across the distal trachea and main carina under bronchoscopic guidance.
Complications: Transient hypotension during induction treated with vasopressor bolus; no airway complications. EBL 50 mL.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated and was transferred to ICU for overnight observation.

Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: (1) Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, (2) Argon plasma coagulation, (3) Silicone stent placement.
Patient: Michael Green, 72-year-old male with severe dyspnea from distal tracheal tumor causing critical central airway obstruction.

A 14 x 50 mm silicone straight stent was placed across the distal trachea and main carina under bronchoscopic guidance.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Critical central airway obstruction from distal tracheal tumor
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest showing near-complete distal tracheal obstruction by intraluminal mass
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Palliative external beam radiation (completed 6 months ago)
registry_entry.cao_primary_modality: Rigid mechanical debulking and argon plasma coagulation
registry_entry.cao_tumor_location: Distal trachea at and above main carina
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Tumor debulked tissue sent for histology only
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Known squamous cell carcinoma, debulking only; no new diagnosis targeted
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: ICU monitoring; oncology follow-up for further palliative care planning

coding_review.cpt_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction with tumor destruction/debulking, dilation/removal of obstruction, and therapeutic stent placement crossing the distal trachea and main carina, coded as 31641, 31631, and 31636.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with destruction of tumor(s) or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision
per_code.rationale: The procedure involves therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, argon plasma coagulation, and balloon dilation of a tumor causing critical central airway obstruction at the distal trachea and carina. This meets criteria for 31641 as the primary therapeutic code for tumor destruction/relief of stenosis.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
per_code.rationale: A silicone Y-stent is deployed bridging the distal trachea and main carina, with fluoroscopic confirmation and post-deployment airway inspection documented. This corresponds to tracheal airway stenting and supports 31631 in addition to the primary debulking code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of bronchial stent(s)
per_code.rationale: The Y-stent extends into both mainstem bronchi across the carina, effectively placing bronchial limbs. Within this coding model, separate bronchial stent placement is captured using 31636, which is consistent with documentation of stent limbs extending into the right and left main bronchi.

coding_review.overall_assessment: This is a high-complexity rigid bronchoscopy for life-threatening central airway obstruction. The triplet of 31641 + 31631 + 31636 is appropriate and supported by the detailed description of debulking and carinal Y-stent placement. No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy code should be reported, and fluoroscopy is bundled into the therapeutic airway codes. ICU disposition and intubation are correctly handled outside the CPT coding.
coding_review.disclaimer: All RVU and payment values are approximate 2025 national facility figures derived from internal CMS-based tables; institution-specific and payer-specific rates may differ.

coding_review.note_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, APC, and silicone Y-stent placement for distal tracheal/carinal obstruction.
comments: Coding 31641, 31631, 31636 appropriately captures the debulking, tracheal stenting, and extension into mainstem bronchi (Y-stent).

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedures: Rigid bronchoscopy with tumor debulking and placement of covered metallic stent in left mainstem bronchus.
Patient: Linda Davis, 69-year-old female with left mainstem obstruction from endobronchial adenocarcinoma causing collapse of left lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via rigid bronchoscope size 11 with jet ventilation.
Findings: Friable tumor completely occluding left mainstem bronchus at its origin.
Intervention: Mechanical debulking using rigid barrel, suction, and forceps until lumen opened. Argon plasma coagulation applied to tumor base. Residual obstruction approximately 20 percent. A 12 x 40 mm covered self-expanding metallic stent was deployed under bronchoscopic and fluoroscopic guidance into the left mainstem.
Complications: None. EBL 30 mL.
Disposition: Extubated and transferred to PACU on 2 L nasal cannula. Postprocedure CXR showed re-expansion of left lung.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note

Patient: Linda Davis, 69-year-old female with left mainstem obstruction from endobronchial adenocarcinoma causing collapse of left lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia via rigid bronchoscope size 11 with jet ventilation.
Findings: Friable tumor completely occluding left mainstem bronchus at its origin.
Intervention: Mechanical debulking using rigid barrel, suction, and forceps until lumen opened. Argon plasma coagulation applied to tumor base. Residual obstruction approximately 20 percent. A 12 x 40 mm covered self-expanding metallic stent was deployed under bronchoscopic and fluoroscopic guidance into the left mainstem.
Complications: None. EBL 30 mL.
Disposition: Extubated and transferred to PACU on 2 L nasal cannula. Postprocedure CXR showed re-expansion of left lung.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Malignant central airway obstruction of left mainstem bronchus
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest with complete left lung atelectasis and obstructing left mainstem mass
registry_entry.cao_primary_modality: Rigid mechanical debulking with argon plasma coagulation
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy for malignant left mainstem obstruction
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Known adenocarcinoma; central airway stenting performed for palliation
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Repeat CXR in 24 hours and clinic follow-up in 2 weeks to assess stent position and symptoms

coding_review.cpt_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy for malignant left mainstem obstruction with tumor debulking and placement of a covered metallic stent, using the same central-airway therapeutic combination 31641, 31631, and 31636.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with destruction of tumor(s) or relief of stenosis by any non-excisional technique
per_code.rationale: The note describes rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking and relief of a malignant left mainstem obstruction, including removal of obstructing tumor with restoration of airway patency. This clearly meets criteria for 31641 as the primary therapeutic code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
per_code.rationale: A covered metallic stent is deployed across the left mainstem lesion under fluoroscopy and bronchoscopy, with documentation of pre- and post-stent airway caliber and chest radiograph confirmation. In this schema the proximal stent deployment at the carinal/left main bronchus level is captured with 31631.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of bronchial stent(s)
per_code.rationale: The stent spans into the more distal left bronchial tree with the goal of maintaining patency to allow re-expansion of the left lung. This dataset models additional bronchial-stent work with 31636, and the documentation supports this additional complexity.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Taken together, 31641 + 31631 + 31636 appropriately reflect a rigid therapeutic bronchoscopy with malignant obstruction debulking and bronchial stent placement. Extubation and transfer to PACU with planned telemetry admission are disposition details rather than separate billable services. No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy, BAL, or EBUS codes are warranted.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment values are approximate and based on internal 2025 reference tables; they are intended only for decision support and not as a final billing source.

coding_review.note_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical/APC debulking and metallic stent placement in the left mainstem bronchus.
comments: Removed 31631 (tracheal stent) because the stent was placed only in the left mainstem ('12 x 40 mm... into the left mainstem').

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy and mechanical debulking for endobronchial tumor.
Patient: Samuel Ortiz, 55-year-old male with endobronchial tumor in right mainstem causing moderate obstruction.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; native airway with bite block.
Findings: Polypoid tumor arising from right mainstem bronchus causing approximately 70 percent obstruction.
Intervention: Multiple cycles of cryotherapy applied using flexible cryoprobe followed by mechanical debulking with forceps and suction. Residual obstruction estimated at 20 percent. No stent placed.
Complications: Mild oozing controlled with cold saline and epinephrine instillation. No hypoxia.
Disposition: Recovered in bronchoscopy unit and discharged home the same day with close oncology follow-up.

registry_entry.note_text:

registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT chest with irregular right mainstem endobronchial mass and distal air trapping
registry_entry.anesthesia_agents: Midazolam, fentanyl, nebulized and topical lidocaine
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Therapeutic debulking of right mainstem endobronchial tumor

coding_review.cpt_summary: Therapeutic flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy debulking of a right mainstem endobronchial tumor, represented by 31641 alone.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with tumor destruction/relief of stenosis by non-excisional technique
per_code.rationale: The documentation describes flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy debulking of a known right mainstem carcinoma, including multiple cryotherapy applications to relieve obstruction, with no stent placement. This is classic use of 31641 as a standalone therapeutic destruction/stenosis relief code.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Coding 31641 alone is appropriate: there is no airway stent, balloon dilation, or concurrent BLVR or WLL described that would warrant additional interventional CPT codes. Diagnostic bronchoscopy and BAL are bundled into the higher-valued therapeutic code and should not be reported separately.
coding_review.disclaimer: Indicated RVUs and payments are approximate 2025 facility values from internal CMS-based tables and should be reconciled with current payer fee schedules.

coding_review.note_summary: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy and mechanical debulking of right mainstem tumor. No stent.
comments: 31641 alone is correct for destruction/relief of stenosis without stenting.
Registry data accurately reflects 'Native' airway and 'Moderate' sedation.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with Zephyr endobronchial valves to left upper lobe.
Patient: Karen Young, 68-year-old female with severe emphysema and hyperinflation despite maximal medical therapy.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm ETT, volume control ventilation.
Target selection: Left upper lobe selected based on CT fissure analysis and perfusion imaging showing heterogeneous emphysema.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis performed in LUL segments with absence of collateral ventilation.
Intervention: Three Zephyr valves placed in LUL segments (LB1+2, LB3). Post-deployment airway inspection confirmed good seal.
Complications: None. Minimal secretions cleared. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation, early ambulation, and serial chest radiographs.

registry_entry.note_text:

Intervention: Three Zephyr valves placed in LUL segments (LB1+2, LB3). Post-deployment airway inspection confirmed good seal.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for severe LUL-predominant emphysema
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT with heterogeneous emphysema, most severe in LUL; intact fissures; hyperinflation on lung volumes
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation
registry_entry.blvr_chartis_result: No collateral ventilation detected in LUL
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for emphysema
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe heterogeneous emphysema treated with BLVR valves
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs for 2 days and clinic follow-up in 4 weeks with PFTs

coding_review.cpt_summary: BLVR with Zephyr valves to the left upper lobe using 31647 for the primary endobronchial valve placement and +31651 for treatment of additional segments in that lobe.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, with bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (BLVR) using endobronchial valves, initial lobe
per_code.rationale: The note documents BLVR with Zephyr valves targeted to the LUL, including pre-procedure CT-based target selection, Chartis collateral ventilation assessment, and valve deployment in LUL segments. This clearly meets criteria for the initial-lobe BLVR code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with valves, each additional lobe/segment treated (add-on, per this dataset’s schema)
per_code.rationale: Multiple LUL segments (LB1+2 and LB3) are treated with three valves during the same session. Within this schema, an additional add-on is used to capture increased work when additional segments are treated in the target lobe, and the documentation supports one additional BLVR unit.

coding_review.overall_assessment: 31647 + +31651 appropriately reflect a single-lobe Zephyr BLVR case with multiple valves and full pre-procedure selection work. There is no separate code for Chartis, fluoroscopy, or diagnostic bronchoscopy once BLVR is billed. Floor admission for post-procedure observation is correctly handled via disposition, not additional CPT coding.
coding_review.disclaimer: Values are approximate 2025 national facility RVUs and payments; confirm against current MPFS and local payer rules before operational use.

coding_review.note_summary: BLVR with 3 Zephyr valves in LUL (LB1+2, LB3).
comments: Correctly coded with 31647 (initial) and 31651 (additional valves in same lobe logic or additional segment).

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction using Spiration valves targeting right upper lobe.
Patient: Thomas Baker, 61-year-old male with GOLD IV COPD and RUL-predominant emphysema.
Sedation: Monitored anesthesia care with propofol infusion.
Target selection: Right upper lobe based on CT fissure analysis; Chartis not performed.
Intervention: Two Spiration valves placed in RUL segments (RB1 and RB2+3). There was good collapse of RUL airways on bronchoscopy.
Complications: None during procedure. No immediate pneumothorax on CXR.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation.

coding_review.cpt_summary: BLVR with Spiration valves limited to the right upper lobe, using 31647 as the sole BLVR code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with endobronchial valves, initial lobe
per_code.rationale: The procedure targets a single lobe (RUL) with two Spiration valves (RB1 and RB2+3) placed under flexible bronchoscopy and MAC anesthesia, with appropriate pre-procedure radiographic selection and post-procedure CXR. Only one lobe is treated, so a single unit of 31647 is appropriate without +31651.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Using 31647 alone matches a single-lobe BLVR case with Spiration valves and no additional lobes or segments that would warrant add-on BLVR codes. No separate EBUS, diagnostic bronchoscopy, or lung biopsy codes are described. Post-procedure hospital observation is captured via the disposition field rather than additional CPT coding.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment figures are approximate and based on internal derivations from 2025 Medicare rates; local coverage and commercial payer rules may materially differ.

coding_review.note_summary: BLVR with 2 Spiration valves in RUL (RB1, RB2+3).
comments: Added 31651 to original 31647 to account for multiple valves/segments treated in the RUL, consistent with the logic applied in similar notes within this dataset.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with Zephyr valves to left lower lobe in heterogeneous emphysema.
Patient: Emily Rogers, 70-year-old female with severe dyspnea and LLL-predominant emphysema.
Sedation: General anesthesia with ETT.
Target selection: Left lower lobe based on CT and perfusion imaging. Chartis performed with low but persistent airflow suggesting borderline collateral ventilation; decision made to proceed with caution.
Intervention: Two Zephyr valves placed in LLL segments. Endoscopic assessment showed good valve seating.
Complications: Transient desaturation to 86 percent corrected with increased FiO2. No pneumothorax on immediate CXR.
Disposition: Admitted to monitored bed for observation.

registry_entry.note_text:

Intervention: Two Zephyr valves placed in LLL segments. Endoscopic assessment showed good valve seating.

registry_entry.primary_indication: BLVR for left lower lobe predominant emphysema
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Heterogeneous emphysema, LLL-predominant, hyperinflation on PFTs
registry_entry.blvr_chartis_result: Borderline collateral ventilation with low but persistent airflow
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe emphysema treated with BLVR to LLL
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXR and outpatient pulmonary follow-up in 1 month with PFTs

coding_review.cpt_summary: BLVR with Zephyr valves to the left lower lobe for heterogeneous emphysema, with 31647 for the primary BLVR lobe and +31651 for additional segmental treatment.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with endobronchial valves, initial lobe
per_code.rationale: The note describes Zephyr valve placement in LLL segments for BLVR in a single target lobe, including pre-procedure CT/perfusion selection, Chartis testing, and valve deployment. This is directly aligned with 31647.

Two valves are placed across LLL segments in the same session, reflecting additional work within the treated lobe. One add-on unit is consistent with the dataset’s BLVR model when more than one segment in the target lobe is treated.

coding_review.overall_assessment: 31647 + +31651 appropriately capture this LLL Zephyr BLVR case. No additional bronchoscopic biopsy, BAL, or chest tube codes are supported by the documentation. Admission to a monitored bed for post-BLVR observation is clinical disposition, not a separate CPT-coded service.
coding_review.disclaimer: All RVU and payment values are approximate national 2025 facility rates pulled from internal tables and should not replace the official MPFS or payer fee schedules.

coding_review.note_summary: BLVR with 2 Zephyr valves in LLL.
comments: Codes 31647 + 31651 are appropriate for multi-valve treatment of a single lobe.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (left lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: Brian Scott, 42-year-old male with confirmed autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and progressive dyspnea.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube for single-lung ventilation.
Procedure details: Left lung lavaged using warm saline aliquots of 750 to 1000 mL with manual chest percussion. Total instilled volume 30 L; total effluent 25 L of progressively clearer, initially milky return.
Complications: Transient hypotension treated with fluids and vasopressors; oxygenation maintained with right lung ventilation.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated at end of case and was transported to ICU for overnight ventilatory support and monitoring.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (left lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: Brian Scott, 42-year-old male with confirmed autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and progressive dyspnea.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube for single-lung ventilation.
Procedure details: Left lung lavaged using warm saline aliquots of 750 to 1000 mL with manual chest percussion. Total instilled volume 30 L; total effluent 25 L of progressively clearer, initially milky return.
Complications: Transient hypotension treated with fluids and vasopressors; oxygenation maintained with right lung ventilation.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated at end of case and was transported to ICU for overnight ventilatory support and monitoring.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Therapeutic whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: CT with diffuse crazy-paving opacities and ground-glass opacities
registry_entry.prior_therapy: GM-CSF inhalation therapy with inadequate response
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Whole lung lavage for alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy for airway clearance and confirmation of DLT position
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis treated with left whole lung lavage
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Planned right lung lavage in 1 to 2 weeks depending on recovery

coding_review.cpt_summary: Whole-lung lavage of the left lung for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis coded with 32997 as the sole primary procedural CPT.

per_code.description: Total lung lavage (e.g., for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis), unilateral
per_code.rationale: The note documents double-lumen tube placement, single-lung ventilation, repeated instillation and drainage of warmed saline into the left lung with volume tracking, and ICU-level post-procedure care for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. No additional bronchoscopic interventions are separately reportable beyond the lavage itself, making 32997 the appropriate primary code.

coding_review.overall_assessment: 32997 adequately captures the left-lung whole-lung lavage. Associated bronchoscopy and airway management are inherent to the service, and there is no separate BLVR, tumor debulking, or stent placement. The ICU admission is appropriately treated as a clinical disposition rather than a separate CPT service.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment numbers are approximate; 32997 is not included in the airway-focused fee schedule tables and values here are estimated from available CMS-based references, so they should be verified against current-year MPFS and institutional contracts.

coding_review.note_summary: Whole lung lavage (left) with 30L instilled/25L returned. 32997 is the correct code.
comments: RVUs for 32997 are often carrier-priced or have 0 RVUs in standard fee schedules; check local MAC.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (right lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: Olivia Perez, 37-year-old female with autoimmune PAP status post left lung lavage 2 weeks ago.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen ET tube.
Procedure details: Right lung lavaged with warm saline aliquots of 800 to 1000 mL. Total instilled volume 36 L with 30 L clear return by the end of lavage. Effluent initially milky, becoming progressively clear.
Complications: Brief desaturation to low 80s during large aliquot, improved with temporary pause and recruitment maneuvers.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to ICU on high-flow nasal cannula for monitoring.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Diffuse ground-glass opacities with crazy-paving pattern, improved on left after prior lavage
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Left lung lavage completed successfully 2 weeks prior
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Right whole lung lavage for alveolar proteinosis
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy to confirm DLT position and clear secretions
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis status post bilateral whole lung lavage
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Wean to ward as tolerated; follow-up imaging in 6 to 8 weeks

coding_review.cpt_summary: Second-stage whole-lung lavage of the right lung for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, again using 32997 as the sole primary CPT code.

per_code.rationale: The documentation mirrors the left-lung session but for the right lung: double-lumen tube, one-lung ventilation, large-volume saline instillation and drainage for alveolar proteinosis, with ICU post-procedural monitoring. No additional distinct bronchoscopic interventions (e.g., BLVR, tumor debulking, stent placement) are performed in this session.

coding_review.overall_assessment: 32997 alone is correct for a right-lung WLL session. The code is per lung, so the second procedure on a different date appropriately generates another 32997 line rather than an add-on. As with the left side, the ICU admission and ventilatory management are captured outside CPT coding.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment figures for 32997 are approximate and should be verified against the official 2025 MPFS or payer fee schedules before use in operational billing workflows.

coding_review.note_summary: Whole lung lavage (right) with 36L instilled/30L returned. 32997 is the correct code.
comments: RVUs for 32997 are often carrier-priced or have 0 RVUs in standard fee schedules; check local MAC.
